post.html:
been reading "City of Bits: Space, Place and the Infobahn" by William J Mitchell, dean of urban planning @ MIT (?). Written 1995 (?)—so it's old! but is very interesting regardless, predicted many things about the internet — interesting experience reading things and then thinking about how they materialized in real life (or not!)

Compares the internet to a city (not quite, but very generally) — give some examples of how cyberspace has changed how we interact with the world, and how that changes how we go about our lives

  • the abstract concept?
  • see the last chapter (7)

Also examines how the fundamental principles guiding civic life have changed with cyberspace, and asks some important questions that we still don't quite have answers to (privacy? something else? see folded pages)

See what he said about the internet allows for a truly global society (beginning of last section in chapter 7). The new architects and urban planners of the 21st century will shape the city of bits, and this global society

This book does a really good job of demonstrating how the internet, in the end, is a new mode of human connection, just like a city. It's far more than a collection of software—in fact, the software is only the means by which we can form new kinds of human connections, and by extension, human societies both on the internet and off of it.

As a software engineering student, I'm really learning how to be an architect of a new civic society. As an architect, it's my role to understand how to facilitate these human connections to build a more connected, peaceful, ?? future.

frontmatter.title: The Web as a City
frontmatter.description: I've been thinking about this quote from the Japanese architect Arata Isozaki: "Extravagance is, for me, complete silence."
